premises: If a sorting algorithm is efficient, then it saves time
incorrect conclusions: If it saves time, then a sorting algorithm is efficient
If it does not save time, then a sorting algorithm is efficient
If a sorting algorithm is not efficient, then it does not save time

premises: If a programming language is object-oriented, then it supports encapsulation
incorrect conclusions: If it supports encapsulation, then a programming language is object-oriented
If it does not support encapsulation, then a programming language is object-oriented
If a programming language is not object-oriented, then it does not support encapsulation

premises: If a network is secure, then it uses encryption
incorrect conclusions: If it uses encryption, then a network is secure
If it does not use encryption, then a network is secure
If a network is not secure, then it does not use encryption
